dataset.title: The importance of fig characteristics for fig wasp morphospecies and diversity

abstract.para: Ficus sycomorus is a keystone species on a macro level but yet is highly dependent on the fig wasps for its reproductive success. The relationship between F. sycomorus and fig wasps has been largely studied in ecology. More importantly, the relationship is an ideal model for co-evolutionary processes. It is thus essential to study what fig characteristics facilitate wasp populations inside figs. In this study, the influence of ripeness and size of the fig as well as location and human influence on the figsâ€™ habitat were examined as possible determinants of wasp diversity in figs. After surveying 13 crops of F. sycomorus inflorescence, a total of 12 morphospecies were identified. We found that ripeness, location, and human disturbance are the key characteristics for species diversity. Fruit diameter did not show any relation with wasp diversity or abundance. Ripeness, at a micro scale, is an effective tool for selecting figs with high wasp morphospecies diversity. We found that F. sycomorus occurring in riparian areas and non-human impacted areas have higher species diversity.

keywordSet.keyword: morphospecie diversity, Ficus sycomorus, fig wasp, keystone species

section.title: Site
section.para: Site. Trees were collected from two locations: the riparian area around the Sabie River and the Skukuza village of the Pretoriaskop area (Skukuza, Kruger National Park, Mpumalanga Province, South Africa) between October 10th and October 12th (Sabie River GPS: 24.99008S, 31.45679E; Skukuza village GPS: 24.79372S, 31.59014E).

section.title: Tree Selection
section.para: Thirteen trees were selected from two habitat types: seven riparian trees along the Sabie River and six non-riparian trees within the Skukuza Camp (Figure 1).

section.title: Fig collection and assesment
section.para: Samples of 10-13 figs were selected from each tree at random. Figs were individually placed into vials with mesh tops to allow the wasps to breathe.Fig color, softness, and diameter were measured. Fig color score was assessed on a scale of 1-5; 1=light green, 5=yellowish-tan. Softness score was assessed by touch on a scale of 1-5; 1=hard, 5=soft. Softness and color scores were added to form a ripeness score of 1-10.

section.title: Wasp collection
section.para: The wasps were allowed to emerge for a total of three days in the presence of ethyl acetate in a large closed box to kill the wasps as they emerged. Wasps were collected from individual vials at time >24, >48, and >72 hours. After the emergence period, wasps were individually counted and sorted based on morphology under a dissecting scope. Morphological features were used to assess the morphospecies identified. A morphospecies is a simple classification to categorize communities based on morphology. Morphologies were distinguished based on body color, leg color, body size, ovipositor length, jaw-size, and antenna shape.

section.title: Analyses
section.para: In order to organize the data, the ripeness score of figs was categorized in order to simplify the analysis process. Using this score, a regression analysis was used to separate the data into three groups: Group 1 (under ripe with ripeness score of 2-3), Group 2 (ripe with ripeness score 4-9), and Group 3 (overripe with ripeness score 10) (Figure 2). The analysis of morphospecies diversity for all characteristics was performed on Group 2 because members of this group encompassed the majority of figs surveyed.

Mann-Whitney U tests and Kruskal-Wallis tests were applied to the collected data to determine the differences in the number of morphospecies for the ripeness, location, and human influence factors. A correlation statistic was used to compare the diameter of the fig to both the number of wasps present in the fig and the number of morphospecies. Multidimensional scale ordination (MDS) was used to show degrees of similarity in a graphical depiction. Simpsonâ€™s index of diversity, a nonparametric indication of diversity, was used to calculate morphospecies diversity amongst the fig wasps (Krebs, 1989). Chi-squared tests were used to calculate significance in the presence of parasitoids amongst the different characteristics. Yateâ€™s correction was applied to the chi-squared value as there was only one degree of freedom

attribute.attributeDefinition: Reference number for each individual fig

attribute.attributeDefinition: Location of the tree with respect to human influence (Human = human influenced, river = undisturbed)
